entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: System accent color for accent-color property.
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: System accent color for accent-color property.
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+System+accent+color+for+accent%5C-color+property.%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: System accent color for accent-color property.</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250423" rel="nofollow">Wed, 23 Apr 2025 15:19:25 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails priya...@microsoft.com </pre><pre>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#widget-accent">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#widget-accent</a>
Summary
This feature empowers web developers to enhance the visual appeal of their websites by leveraging the operating system's accent color for form elements. By utilizing the "accent-color" CSS property, developers can ensure that form elements such as checkboxes, radio buttons, and progress bars automatically adopt the accent color defined by the user's operating system. This feature is an enhancement to existing feature that is already shipped in Chromium: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA</a>
Blink component Blink>CSS
Search tags accent-color, accent, color, system accent color
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping Firefox currently supports this feature on Mac and Linux platforms.
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
When the platform's accent color is utilized for the "accent-color" CSS property, either due to the absence of a specified value or when set to "auto," the getComputedStyle() JS function returns "auto" instead of the actual hexadecimal value of the color being applied. Related link: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6158">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6158</a>
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No This feature is currently supported on Windows, macOS, and ChromeOS. Future work for Linux is planned and can be tracked at the following link: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/391917949">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/391917949</a>. Android features a setting for accent color, and we plan to add support for Android in the future. The strategy is to release this feature incrementally, allowing web developers to provide feedback and assess the necessity of allocating additional resources for other less requested platforms.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-visited.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-visited.tentative.html</a> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-parsing.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-parsing.html</a> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-computed.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-computed.html</a> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-typed-om/the-stylepropertymap/properties/accent-color.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-typed-om/the-stylepropertymap/properties/accent-color.html</a> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/animation/accent-color-interpolation.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/animation/accent-color-interpolation.html</a> Note: The provided links are WPT for the accent-color property, including scenarios where the value is set to "auto." This feature relies on the platform's accent color and necessitates a WebDriver extension to simulate the accent-color property accurately. To ensure consistent testing with WPT, we would need to look into WebDriver API to support this functionality properly.
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name CSSSystemAccentColor
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40764875">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40764875</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 137
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None

<pre>Contact emails schen...@chromium.org, z...@igalia.com </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#caret-shape">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#caret-shape</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#caret-shape">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#caret-shape</a>
Summary
The shape of the caret in native applications is most commonly a vertical bar, an underscore or a rectangular block. In addition, the shape often varies depending on the input mode, such as insert or replace. The CSS caret-shape property allows sites to choose one of these shapes for the caret inside editable elements, or leave the choice up to the browser. The recognized property values are auto, bar, block and underscore.
Blink component Blink>CSS
Motivation
To allow authors to specify the desired shape of the text insertion caret.
Initial public proposal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#caret-shape">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui/#caret-shape</a>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Add prefetchCache and prerenderCache to Clear-Site-Data header
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Add prefetchCache and prerenderCache to Clear-Site-Data header
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Add+prefetchCache+and+prerenderCache+to+Clear%5C-Site%5C-Data+header%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Add prefetchCache and prerenderCache to Clear-Site-Data header</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250425" rel="nofollow">Fri, 25 Apr 2025 09:24:56 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails steven...@microsoft.com </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/nav-speculation/blob/main/clear-site-data-integration.md">https://github.com/WICG/nav-speculation/blob/main/clear-site-data-integration.md</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6456388">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6456388</a>
Summary
We propose adding two new values to the Clear-Site-Data header to help developers target clearing the prerender and prefetch cache: “prefetchCache” and “prerenderCache”.
Blink component Blink>Loader>Preload
Motivation
Currently, the only way to clear the prefetch and prerender cache is through either the Clear-Site-Data header "cache" value or manually having the UA clear their browsing data cache. With the increased adoption of Speculation Rules, developers want a way to target specifically clearing prefetches, prerenders, or both, without disrupting other session information, such as history, cookies, etc. By adding "prefetchCache" and "prerenderCache" values to the Clear-Site-Data response headers, there is an option to target only these specific caches.
Initial public proposal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1OWMmGHvXDAM1VYOP2TDP2c7GWJ5ucNxFwFQQVlGdmQ4/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1OWMmGHvXDAM1VYOP2TDP2c7GWJ5ucNxFwFQQVlGdmQ4/edit?usp=sharing</a>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Pass 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' header with <link rel=prefetch>
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Pass 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' header with <link rel=prefetch>
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A++Pass+%27Sec%5C-Purpose%5C%3A+prefetch%27+header+with+%3Clink+rel%3Dprefetch%3E%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Pass 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' header with <link rel=prefetch></span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250428" rel="nofollow">Mon, 28 Apr 2025 10:11:44 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails steven...@microsoft.com </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/resource-hints/issues/74">https://github.com/w3c/resource-hints/issues/74</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6334746">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6334746</a>
Summary
Chrome currently passes both 'Purpose: prefetch' and 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' headers as part of prefetch through speculation rules. However, only 'Purpose: prefetch' is passed with <link rel=prefetch>. We plan to standardize this header for both speculation rules and <link rel=prefetch> by adding 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' header to the latter. Future work will involve stop sending 'Purpose: prefetch' for prefetches, prerenders, etc.
Blink component Blink>Loader
Motivation
SpeculationRules prefetch does send Sec-Purpose: "prefetch" header, but rel="prefetch" does not. The purpose headers allows servers to discern between regular requests and "resource hints" (requests that are only meant to populate caches).
Initial public proposal None
TAG review Not filed as this is a minor change of unspec'ed UA behavior for an existing feature. (Can start a review if recommended)
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
As commented at notes on Firefox and Safari, each browser uses non-standardized header name that is not aligned with CORS spec. This change will introduce better interoperability and compatibility for a long term.
Gecko: No signal Firefox has sent 'X-moz: prefetch'.
WebKit: No signal Safari has sent 'Purpose: prefetch' but changed to use 'X-Purpose: preview'.
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No Plan to add a new test.

Non-finch justification None
Requires code in //chrome? False

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Cache+sharing+for+extremely%5C-pervasive+scripts%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive scripts</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250430" rel="nofollow">Wed, 30 Apr 2025 04:01:46 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Thanks Patrick. It will be interesting to learn how the experiment goes, </tt><tt>and any possible improvements, especially if resources are changing hourly. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>I look forward to learning more about how sites will attest to always </tt><tt>return the same payload, if the experiment proves successful. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>One last question: which milestones are you requesting to run the </tt><tt>experiment for? Your chromestatus entry doesn't indicate that - I think </tt><tt>you need to add an experiment milestone (which is probably why this </tt><tt>intent didn't show up in our review queue). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On 4/29/25 2:20 PM, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>The previous experiment required an exact match of a full URL and </tt><tt>payload hash (on a path to automate allow-listing responses). </tt><tt>Unfortunately, most of the interesting third-party resources are </tt><tt>updated quite regularly (usually at least daily if not every few </tt><tt>hours) so the URL list and payload hashes were both very stale by the </tt><tt>time the experiment was run. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>This experiment learned from those results and is targeting a MUCH </tt><tt>smaller list of manually curated resources that are much more popular </tt><tt>and uses a URLPattern to allow for versioned variants of the URLs (for </tt><tt>things like the YT player JS or pubads_impl which include versions in </tt><tt>the path) and removes the hash-matching requirement for the payload </tt><tt>(for things like analytics.js which update in-place). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>It won't impact as many third-party resources, by design, but the </tt><tt>resources that it does impact are going to be MUCH more likely to be </tt><tt>seen by most users multiple times within a browsing session (and </tt><tt>within the update window for any of them). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Tue, Apr 29, 2025 at 10:52 AM Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Hey Patrick,
This sounds related to a previous experiment
(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/9xWJK3IgJb4/m/SYLfUccOBgAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/9xWJK3IgJb4/m/SYLfUccOBgAJ</a>) - could you describe how this experiment is similar or different (or perhaps builds upon the results from the previous experiment)?
thanks, Mike
On 4/23/25 10:46 AM, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Contact emails
pmee...@chromium.org
Specification
None
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing</a>
Summary
For a small number (hundreds) of hand-curated static third-party scripts that are used on a large portion of the web, Chrome will use a single-keyed HTTP cache to store those resources. This helps users and site owners with faster performance for those scripts that are very widely used while maintaining the privacy protections of the partitioned disk cache. This feature targets the scripts that most users are likely to see multiple times across multiple sites in any given browsing session. They are usually not in the critical path of the page loading and may not impact the common performance metrics but they are still important for the healthy operation of the web. The list of candidate scripts is curated from the HTTP Archive dataset. This includes site-independent things like common analytics scripts, social media embeds, video player embeds, captcha providers and ads libraries. It allows for code that uses versioned URLs as long as the versioning is not a manual process by embedders and that the same version is sent to everybody at a given point in time with the same contents. This does not include things like common Javascript libraries where they are commonly self-hosted or where the URL references a specific version of the library and it is up to site owners to manually select a version.
Blink component
Blink>Network
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This change is internal to Chrome and should be completely transparent to the web platform with no interoperability risks.
/Gecko/: N/A
/WebKit/: N/A
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
Ergonomics
N/A
Activation
N/A
Security
Cache partitioning added a level of privacy protection that is being disabled for a small number of resources where it is deemed safe to do so. The linked document and issue provide the details on the protections that are in place to minimize the privacy exposure.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
For the purposes of the experiment, we will target around a dozen of the most-impactful scripts (mostly ads and analytics) and work with the script owners to measure the resulting impact (on performance, reliability and business metrics).
If these scripts show minimal impact from using a shared cache then there is no value in the added complexity for the feature and it can be documented and closed.
If there is significant impact then it is likely worth pursuing further (and will also be documented for other similar efforts).
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
The cache key used for any given resource is exposed in the netlog <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/for-testers/providing-network-details/">https://www.chromium.org/for-testers/providing-network-details/</a>> which can be used to verify if a given resource used the shared cache or not.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes

<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
No
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
CacheSharingForPervasiveScripts
Non-finch justification
None
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/404196743">https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/404196743</a>
Measurement
The success of this feature will be measured directly with the owners of a small number of targeted scripts with a web-exposed experiment.
Estimated milestones

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive scripts
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive scripts
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Cache+sharing+for+extremely%5C-pervasive+scripts%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive scripts</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250430" rel="nofollow">Wed, 30 Apr 2025 04:02:54 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>The design doc also links to </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hW-xXj9zEdkTJMVE4b4qcflB00WxsOG72Y0LVtSjcWI/edit?gid=1602510613#gid=1602510613">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hW-xXj9zEdkTJMVE4b4qcflB00WxsOG72Y0LVtSjcWI/edit?gid=1602510613#gid=1602510613</a>, </tt><tt>and an HTTP archive query to produce it. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On 4/30/25 5:07 AM, Jxck wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Experiment candidates in Design docs only includes</pre><pre>
* google-analytics.com * googlesyndication.com * doubleclick.net * googletagmanager.com * googleapis.com * youtube.com * etc
</pre><tt>Even if this list were based on a neutral data analysis, it can't help </tt><tt>thinking that Chrome is intended to ship changes that are only </tt><tt>benefits for Google's business. </tt><tt>On Wednesday, April 30, 2025 at 6:02:20 AM UTC+9 </tt><tt>danielher...@gmail.com wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Personally I'm not a fan of this idea of giving special performance boosts to big properties like YouTube or Google Ads. That's creating an unfair advantage over smaller players in the market. And I have to point out that Google is currently under antitrust scrutiny for allegedly doing such.
On Tue, Apr 29, 2025 at 2:20 PM Patrick Meenan <pmee...@chromium.org> wrote:
The previous experiment required an exact match of a full URL and payload hash (on a path to automate allow-listing responses). Unfortunately, most of the interesting third-party resources are updated quite regularly (usually at least daily if not every few hours) so the URL list and payload hashes were both very stale by the time the experiment was run.
This experiment learned from those results and is targeting a MUCH smaller list of manually curated resources that are much more popular and uses a URLPattern to allow for versioned variants of the URLs (for things like the YT player JS or pubads_impl which include versions in the path) and removes the hash-matching requirement for the payload (for things like analytics.js which update in-place).
It won't impact as many third-party resources, by design, but the resources that it does impact are going to be MUCH more likely to be seen by most users multiple times within a browsing session (and within the update window for any of them).
On Tue, Apr 29, 2025 at 10:52 AM Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org> wrote:
Hey Patrick,
This sounds related to a previous experiment
(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/9xWJK3IgJb4/m/SYLfUccOBgAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/9xWJK3IgJb4/m/SYLfUccOBgAJ</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/9xWJK3IgJb4/m/SYLfUccOBgAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/9xWJK3IgJb4/m/SYLfUccOBgAJ</a>>) - could you describe how this experiment is similar or different (or perhaps builds upon the results from the previous experiment)?
thanks, Mike
On 4/23/25 10:46 AM, Patrick Meenan wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Contact emails
pmee...@chromium.org
Specification
None
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xaoF9iSOojrlPrHZaKIJMK4iRZKA3AD6pQvbSy4ueUQ/edit?usp=sharing</a>>
Summary
For a small number (hundreds) of hand-curated static third-party scripts that are used on a large portion of the web, Chrome will use a single-keyed HTTP cache to store those resources. This helps users and site owners with faster performance for those scripts that are very widely used while maintaining the privacy protections of the partitioned disk cache. This feature targets the scripts that most users are likely to see multiple times across multiple sites in any given browsing session. They are usually not in the critical path of the page loading and may not impact the common performance metrics but they are still important for the healthy operation of the web. The list of candidate scripts is curated from the HTTP Archive dataset. This includes site-independent things like common analytics scripts, social media embeds, video player embeds, captcha providers and ads libraries. It allows for code that uses versioned URLs as long as the versioning is not a manual process by embedders and that the same version is sent to everybody at a given point in time with the same contents. This does not include things like common Javascript libraries where they are commonly self-hosted or where the URL references a specific version of the library and it is up to site owners to manually select a version.
Blink component
Blink>Network
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This change is internal to Chrome and should be completely transparent to the web platform with no interoperability risks.
/Gecko/: N/A
/WebKit/: N/A
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
Ergonomics
N/A
Activation
N/A
Security
Cache partitioning added a level of privacy protection that is being disabled for a small number of resources where it is deemed safe to do so. The linked document and issue provide the details on the protections that are in place to minimize the privacy exposure.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
For the purposes of the experiment, we will target around a dozen of the most-impactful scripts (mostly ads and analytics) and work with the script owners to measure the resulting impact (on performance, reliability and business metrics).
If these scripts show minimal impact from using a shared cache then there is no value in the added complexity for the feature and it can be documented and closed.
If there is significant impact then it is likely worth pursuing further (and will also be documented for other similar efforts).
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
The cache key used for any given resource is exposed in the netlog <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chromium.org/for-testers/providing-network-details/">https://www.chromium.org/for-testers/providing-network-details/</a>> which can be used to verify if a given resource used the shared cache or not.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
No
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
CacheSharingForPervasiveScripts
Non-finch justification
None
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/404196743">https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/404196743</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/404196743">https://issues.chromium.org/u/1/issues/404196743</a>>
Measurement
The success of this feature will be measured directly with the owners of a small number of targeted scripts with a web-exposed experiment.
Estimated milestones
No milestones specified

</pre><tt>Yes, the I2S proposes using the system accent color when the value is </tt><tt>set to "auto". To clarify, "auto" is also the default option if no </tt><tt>value is provided. Therefore, if the accent-color is not explicitly </tt><tt>set, the form elements will automatically use the system accent color </tt><tt>by default. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Thanks, Priya ------------------------------------------------------------------------ *From:* Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org> *Sent:* Tuesday, April 29, 2025 7:46 AM </pre><tt>*To:* Alex Russell <slightly...@chromium.org>; blink-dev </tt><tt><blink-dev@chromium.org> </tt><tt>*Cc:* Chromestatus <ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com>; Alison Maher </tt><tt><alma...@microsoft.com>; Howard Wolosky </tt><tt><howard.wolo...@microsoft.com>; Joey Arhar <jar...@chromium.org>; Hoch </tt><tt>Hochkeppel (HE/HIM) <mho...@microsoft.com>; Natasha Gaitonde </tt><tt><nagai...@microsoft.com>; Priya Palanisamy <priya...@microsoft.com> </tt><tt>*Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: System </tt><tt>accent color for accent-color property. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>You don't often get email from miketa...@chromium.org. Contact emails
priya...@microsoft.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:priya...@microsoft.com">mailto:priya...@microsoft.com</a>>
Explainer
None
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#widget-accent">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#widget-accent</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#widget-accent">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#widget-accent</a>>
Summary
This feature empowers web developers to enhance the visual appeal of their websites by leveraging the operating system's accent color for form elements. By utilizing the "accent-color" CSS property, developers can ensure that form elements such as checkboxes, radio buttons, and progress bars automatically adopt the accent color defined by the user's operating system. This feature is an enhancement to existing feature that is already shipped in Chromium: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA</a>>
Blink component
Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
Search tags
accent-color <<a rel="nofollow" href="http:///features#tags:accent-color">http:///features#tags:accent-color</a>>, accent <<a rel="nofollow" href="http:///features#tags:accent">http:///features#tags:accent</a>>, color <<a rel="nofollow" href="http:///features#tags:color">http:///features#tags:color</a>>, system accent color <<a rel="nofollow" href="http:///features#tags:system%20accent%20color">http:///features#tags:system%20accent%20color</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
/Gecko/: Shipped/Shipping Firefox currently supports this feature on Mac and Linux platforms.
/WebKit/: No signal
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
When the platform's accent color is utilized for the "accent-color" CSS property, either due to the absence of a specified value or when set to "auto," the getComputedStyle() JS function returns "auto" instead of the actual hexadecimal value of the color being applied. Related link: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6158">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6158</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6158">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6158</a>>
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No
This feature is currently supported on Windows, macOS, and ChromeOS. Future work for Linux is planned and can be tracked at the following link: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/391917949">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/391917949</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/391917949">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/391917949</a>>. Android features a setting for accent color, and we plan to add support for Android in the future. The strategy is to release this feature incrementally, allowing web developers to provide feedback and assess the necessity of allocating additional resources for other less requested platforms.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
- <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-visited.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-visited.tentative.html</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-visited.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-visited.tentative.html</a>> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-parsing.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-parsing.html</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-parsing.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-parsing.html</a>> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-computed.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-computed.html</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-computed.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/accent-color-computed.html</a>> -
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-typed-om/the-stylepropertymap/properties/accent-color.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-typed-om/the-stylepropertymap/properties/accent-color.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-typed-om/the-stylepropertymap/properties/accent-color.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-typed-om/the-stylepropertymap/properties/accent-color.html</a>> - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/animation/accent-color-interpolation.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/animation/accent-color-interpolation.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/animation/accent-color-interpolation.html">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-ui/animation/accent-color-interpolation.html</a>> Note: The provided links are WPT for the accent-color property, including scenarios where the value is set to "auto." This feature relies on the platform's accent color and necessitates a WebDriver extension to simulate the accent-color property accurately. To ensure consistent testing with WPT, we would need to look into WebDriver API to support this functionality properly.

Summary
This feature empowers web developers to enhance the visual appeal of their websites by leveraging the operating system's accent color for form elements. By utilizing the "accent-color" CSS property, developers can ensure that form elements such as checkboxes, radio buttons, and progress bars automatically adopt the accent color defined by the user's operating system. This feature is an enhancement to existing feature that is already shipped in Chromium: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/WwYkLjbGhoA</a>>

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Implement+and+Ship%5C%3A+isSecurePaymentConfirmationAvailable+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Implement and Ship: isSecurePaymentConfirmationAvailable API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250430" rel="nofollow">Wed, 30 Apr 2025 04:08:59 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On 4/28/25 5:43 PM, Chris Harrelson wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>LGTM1. Please make sure to ping the standards positions with the </tt><tt>updated shape as well. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>On Mon, Apr 28, 2025 at 12:08 PM Stephen McGruer </tt><tt><smcgr...@chromium.org> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
> Conveniently, the various review bits that we now require are not requested at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5165040614768640?gate=5060726757785600">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5165040614768640?gate=5060726757785600</a> (maybe because they didn't exist?). So you could request those now. For API OWNERs - just repinging this thread should be fine.
The various review bits are now approved, for the updated API shape + design!
So requesting a re-review from API OWNERS, thanks. Let me know if it needs to be 3x LGTM or just 1x :). On Wednesday, March 12, 2025 at 6:40:08 PM UTC-4 Mike Taylor wrote:
On 3/10/25 10:12 AM, Stephen McGruer wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> > It may change shape before finally shipping (in particular, I'm musing over whether true/false is sufficient information and whether we could give developers more specific enum reasons without leaking user privacy) - I'll come back to the thread for approval if we want to ship anything substantially different.
We have now decided that indeed we want to do things a little differently, and are proposing (spec issue <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/284">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/284</a>>, spec PR <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/285">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/285</a>>, new design doc
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZgNRqyJyB36ItqUr6vtlJ19rd7fqpS7Vo0w_GSMz0DA/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.4f9946en7wca">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZgNRqyJyB36ItqUr6vtlJ19rd7fqpS7Vo0w_GSMz0DA/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.4f9946en7wca</a>>) an enum of output states instead of a boolean true/false. This hopefully also addresses previous feedback
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/81#issuecomment-1527105768">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/81#issuecomment-1527105768</a>> from Mike West on being more specific about when the API should return true/false.
What's the right process here for re-requesting review? We should probably *at least* go back through privacy review as adding an enum of more-specific reasons that a feature isn't available definitely has a fingerprinting risk! Is it possible to 'reset' stages in chromestatus? </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Conveniently, the various review bits that we now require are not requested at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5165040614768640?gate=5060726757785600">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5165040614768640?gate=5060726757785600</a> (maybe because they didn't exist?). So you could request those now. For API OWNERs - just repinging this thread should be fine. </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Thanks!
On Thursday, January 23, 2025 at 12:58:46 PM UTC-5 Stephen McGruer wrote:
> I'm assuming no other facts on the ground (signals, TAG feedback, etc) have changed in the meantime? If so, then this plan sounds fine to me.
Yes, sorry, no other changes at this time from the wider W3C community. Partners continue to ask for an easier way to feature-detect SPC, and finally we're getting around to delivering!
On Thursday, January 23, 2025 at 11:20:18 AM UTC-5 Chris Harrelson wrote:
On Thu, Jan 23, 2025 at 7:36 AM Stephen McGruer <smcgr...@chromium.org> wrote:
Hey folks,
Can't quite I'm coming back to this thread near on 2 years later 🤣, but wanted to fyi that this didn't actually ship in the end. However, we are finally coming back to it now (honest - I have CLs out
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6194313">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6194313</a>>! :D), and expect to ship this sometime in the coming months. It may change shape before finally shipping (in particular, I'm musing over whether true/false is sufficient information and whether we could give developers more specific enum reasons without leaking user privacy) - I'll come back to the thread for approval if we want to ship anything substantially different.
I'm assuming no other facts on the ground (signals, TAG feedback, etc) have changed in the meantime? If so, then this plan sounds fine to me.
Thanks, Stephen
On Friday, April 28, 2023 at 11:30:27 AM UTC-4 Chris Harrelson wrote:
LGTM3
On Fri, Apr 28, 2023 at 12:22 AM Mike West <mk...@chromium.org> wrote:
LGTM2.
I think it would be valuable to extend the spec PR with more description of the considerations around when the feature is available (see discussion at
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/81#issuecomment-1527105768">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/81#issuecomment-1527105768</a>), but I don't think that will meaningfully change the shape of the API or its meaning in Chromium's implementation.
-mike

This is a Javascript API to provide an easier way to check if the Secure Payment Confirmation[1] feature is available. Currently, the only way to determine SPC’s availability is to create a PaymentRequest with the required parameters[2], which is clunky and difficult in the case where a developer wants to check for SPC before starting to process a payment. entry.title: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts
entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Ignore+Letter+Spacing+in+Cursive+Scripts%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Sejal+Anand%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Sejal Anand' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250502" rel="nofollow">Fri, 02 May 2025 01:01:00 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hi Yoav , Vladimir, The Web Platform Tests pull request is currently under review. I will update the chrome entry with the relevant WPT links and share it with the group once finalized. Please find my inline response below. Have you investigated some sites that may be impacted by that? I think the rendering is certainly more correct for regular speech, but say one was labeling columns by letters with letter spacing. I feel like this would be negatively impacted by the change. I don't image that's common, but having some examples of how letter spacing is currently used with cursive scripts may be a good investigation Although I could not find above mentioned specific example, the spec advises authors to avoid applying letter-spacing to cursive scripts unless they are prepared to accept non-interoperable results. This recommendation highlights that modifying letter-spacing in cursive scripts can lead to inconsistent rendering, potentially disrupting the natural connections between letters. WPTs and web tests have been added to cover few scenarios involving both cursive and non-cursive scripts. On WPTs, what would it take to add the test? I think it's important that these changes that affect certain scripts are tested in WPT. Is it possible to add the required fonts to the fonts directory? I have submitted the WPT pull request for the css/css-text/letter-spacing directory, and it is currently under review. Thank you, Sejal</pre><pre>
________________________________ From: Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) <yoavwe...@chromium.org> Sent: Wednesday, April 30, 2025 6:04 PM To: blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org> Cc: Sejal Anand <sejalan...@microsoft.com>; blin...@chromium.org <blink-dev@chromium.org>; Ragvesh Sharma's Organization (FTE) <ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com>; Chris Harrelson <chris...@chromium.org>; Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org> Subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts
Hey Sejal! Thanks for working on this, as that seems super important! Would you be able to address Vlad's questions regarding the potential compat impact?
On Wednesday, April 23, 2025 at 6:17:38 PM UTC+2 sejal...@microsoft.com wrote: Hi Chris<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:chris...@chromium.org">mailto:chris...@chromium.org</a>>,
This change will result in second 'OK' example mentioned in Spec.
[<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/group/blink-dev/attach/f14d6b6cd768f/image.png?part=0.1&view=1">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/group/blink-dev/attach/f14d6b6cd768f/image.png?part=0.1&view=1</a>]
Thank you, Sejal ________________________________ From: Chris Harrelson <chris...@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:chris...@chromium.org">mailto:chris...@chromium.org</a>>> Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2025 8:51 PM To: Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:miketa...@chromium.org">mailto:miketa...@chromium.org</a>>> Cc: Sejal Anand <sejalan...@microsoft.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com">mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com</a>>>; blink-dev@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org">mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org</a>> <blink-dev@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org">mailto:blink-dev@chromium.org</a>>>; Ragvesh Sharma's Organization (FTE) <ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com">mailto:ragvesh_org_...@microsoft.com</a>>> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts
Hi, could you clarify which of the renderings in the example 27 table<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-3/#cursive-tracking">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-3/#cursive-tracking</a>> will result? Is it the first "good" one or the second?
On Tue, Apr 22, 2025 at 11:18 AM Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:miketa...@chromium.org">mailto:miketa...@chromium.org</a>>> wrote:
On 4/21/25 11:20 PM, 'Sejal Anand' via blink-dev wrote:
Contact emails sejalan...@microsoft.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com">mailto:sejalan...@microsoft.com</a>>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-3/#cursive-tracking">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-3/#cursive-tracking</a>
Summary This feature adds logic to ignore the letter-spacing setting for cursive scripts as specified by the web author, in line with the spec, to ensure that letter spacing does not disrupt word structure and aims to produce better user experience for users relying on cursive scripts. The spec suggests that the UA may apply letter spacing to cursive scripts by translating the total extra space into cursive elongation or compression. Otherwise, if the UA cannot expand text from a cursive script without breaking its cursive connections, it must not apply spacing between any pair of that script’s typographic letter units at all. Ignoring letter spacing altogether for cursive scripts is simpler and helps avoid performance issues as handling spacing for such scripts requires complex calculations to maintain cursive connections and account for script-specific factors like elongation glyphs, typefaces, and calligraphy preferences. With this feature, Chromium ensures that cursive scripts will be readable and properly spaced, even if the fonts don’t have advanced typographic features. The scripts that we are proposing to apply this to in Chromium are Arabic, Hanifi Rohingya, Mandaic, Mongolian, N’Ko, Phags Pa, and Syriac as these scripts are considered cursive as per spec.
Blink component Blink>Fonts<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable Can you say why?
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility Other browsers currently do not support this feature, as there are open bugs for handling letter-spacing settings in cursive scripts. Our implementation introduces a behavior change that aligns with the spec by ignoring letter-spacing settings to preserve script integrity, prioritizing readability. Since this behavior diverges from other browsers, there are interoperability differences. With this change, letter spacing will no longer be applied to cursive scripts, even if specified by web authors. It’s important to note that this could affect sites relying on letter-spacing for cursive scripts.
Can you please say a little more here? Is this going to strictly improve readability, or will there be cases where a site appears "broken" to users or authors as a result of this change?
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1342835">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1342835</a>)
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=195745">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=195745</a>) Can you file formal position requests? Open bugs aren't quite the same thing.
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/harfbuzz/harfbuzz/issues/358">https://github.com/harfbuzz/harfbuzz/issues/358</a>) Three users have noted they are impacted by the CRBug.
Other signals:
WebView application risks Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications? None
Debuggability If I'm trying to figure out why my site is now different between Chromium-based browsers and Firefox, is there anything that DevTools can do to help me?
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>? No No, WPT tests were not added because the third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/fonts directory only contains auxiliary font files used by other tests. However, there is an internal web test for this feature: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/fonts/letter-spacing.html">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/fonts/letter-spacing.html</a> There are few impacted tests where letter spacing is applied on Arabic texts, these are being replaced with Hebrew - <a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/html/canvas/element/text/2d.text.measure.selection-rects-baselines.tentative.html">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/html/canvas/element/text/2d.text.measure.selection-rects-baselines.tentative.html</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/svg/text/textpath-connected-glyphs-expected.png">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/svg/text/textpath-connected-glyphs-expected.png</a>
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name IgnoreLetterSpacingInCursiveScripts
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40618336">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40618336</a>
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 137 Shipping on Android 137 Shipping on WebView 137 Shipping on iOS 137
Anticipated spec changes Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Limiting+Access+to+Local+Fonts%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Limiting Access to Local Fonts</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250405" rel="nofollow">Sat, 05 Apr 2025 10:42:25 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>That seems to be covered in a few places in the explainer, but most </tt><tt>clearly at </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/limiting-local-fonts-access?tab=readme-ov-file#limiting-to-local-fonts-will-break-my-application-what-should-i-do">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/limiting-local-fonts-access?tab=readme-ov-file#limiting-to-local-fonts-will-break-my-application-what-should-i-do</a> </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On 4/3/25 4:32 AM, 'Ashley Gullen' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>Presumably this does not affect the Local Font Access API </tt><tt>(queryLocalFonts())? Once that method has resolved will the returned </tt><tt>fonts then be allowed to be used in font rendering? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>On Wed, 2 Apr 2025 at 22:36, Chromestatus </tt><tt><ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Contact emails
ta...@google.com, riz...@google.com
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/limiting-local-fonts-access?tab=readme-ov-file">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/limiting-local-fonts-access?tab=readme-ov-file</a>
Specification
None
Summary
Limits the fonts websites can use to only the default system fonts installed by the operating system. The unique set of locally installed fonts can be used for cross-site user tracking by measuring the side-effects of font rendering. By restricting user-installed font access, we aim to improve user privacy.
Blink component
Blink>Fonts
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFonts%22</a>>
Motivation
Users have unique font collections on their devices, and this uniqueness can be exploited to track them across the web by analyzing font rendering. This undermines user privacy by allowing websites to re-identify individuals. To mitigate this privacy risk, a solution is needed to limit websites' access to a user's set of locally installed fonts. Recent CSS working group discussions have also brought up the idea of prescribing user agents to not expose user-installed fonts on the web as a privacy protecting measure. These measures mirror Safari’s approach of limiting local font availability by restricting to fonts that are bundled with the operating system by default.
Initial public proposal

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Automatic beacon cross-origin data support (M135)
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Automatic beacon cross-origin data support (M135)
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+ship%5C%3A+Automatic+beacon+cross%5C-origin+data+support+%5C%28M135%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to ship: Automatic beacon cross-origin data support (M135)</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250405" rel="nofollow">Sat, 05 Apr 2025 10:42:49 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> On 3/25/25 11:04 AM, Liam Brady wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> > Note: reading explainer diffs is not great UX.</pre><pre>
Ack. I'll avoid linking explainer diffs directly in the future.
</pre><tt>This section in the FFAR explainer doc </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Fenced_Frames_Ads_Reporting.md#cross-origin-support">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Fenced_Frames_Ads_Reporting.md#cross-origin-support</a>> </tt><tt>should be a much more readable version of what I linked. </tt></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Perfect, thank you.
</pre><tt>One thing I'm having a hard time following: in order for the </tt><tt>cross-origin automatic beacons to work, you need both a top-level frame </tt><tt>to send `ACAER: true`, and the cross-origin embedded frame to send </tt><tt>`AFFAB: true`. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>But then there's mention of the situation where AFFAO:true isn't needed </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Fenced_Frames_Ads_Reporting.md#cross-origin-support:~:text=negating%20the%20need%20for%20the%20document%20to%20be%20served%20with%20the%20Allow%2DFenced%2DFrame%2DAutomatic%2DBeacons%3A%20true%20header">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Fenced_Frames_Ads_Reporting.md#cross-origin-support:~:text=negating%20the%20need%20for%20the%20document%20to%20be%20served%20with%20the%20Allow%2DFenced%2DFrame%2DAutomatic%2DBeacons%3A%20true%20header</a>.> </tt><tt>(because the cross-origin document set `crossOriginExposed: true` within </tt><tt>`setReportEventDataForAutomaticBeacons()`. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Why does that override the need to send the header?
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
> Is it expected that Canary is failing all 4 tests?
</pre><tt>Yes. Most fenced frame tests are currently failing on wpt.fyi </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/fenced-frame?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/fenced-frame?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>> because </tt><tt>they rely on the FencedFrameConfig constructor (see: </tt><tt>chrome://flags#enable-fenced-frames-developer-mode) that is not </tt><tt>enabled by default. This feature will be enabled by default once we </tt><tt>launch fenced frames with local unpartitioned data access </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5072963051454464">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5072963051454464</a>>, and the tests </tt><tt>should start passing then. Note that these tests are all passing on </tt><tt>the Chromium build bots where the feature is turned on. </tt></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Makes sense, thanks. </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Monday, March 24, 2025 at 9:54:40 AM UTC-4 mike...@chromium.org wrote:
On 3/19/25 1:16 PM, 'Liam Brady' via blink-dev wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Contact emails
lbr...@google.com, shiva...@chromium.org, jka...@chromium.org
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1386">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1386</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1386">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/pull/1386</a>>
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Note: reading explainer diffs is not great UX.
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/fenced-frame/pull/203">https://github.com/WICG/fenced-frame/pull/203</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/fenced-frame/pull/203">https://github.com/WICG/fenced-frame/pull/203</a>>
Summary
This change allows descendant documents of fenced frames to set the root fenced frame’s automatic beacon reporting data, regardless of origin. Both the root fenced frame and the cross-origin data setting document must opt in for this to be allowed.
More detail:
Fenced frames or URN iframes, if loaded through an API like Protected Audience or Shared Storage, can send out reporting beacons automatically if some event occurs (currently only top-level navigation beacons are supported). We previously tweaked this feature to allow cross-origin documents loaded in the root fenced frame's tree to send automatic beacons if opted in, but still kept the restriction that only frames that are same-origin to the origin loaded by the API could set the data that would be sent as part of the beacon.
The existing setup assumes that payload data will only ever come from the buyer directly. However, there are cases where a buyer embeds a cross-origin subpage that contains data that needs to be sent with an automatic beacon. This limitation forces the same-origin root document to be an intermediary between the page with the data and the automatic beacon API, causing unnecessary extra overhead and forcing extra data to be sent directly to the root fenced frame.
To support this use case while still ensuring security guarantees (mainly that a given frame's data cannot be sent across origins without its consent), both the fenced frame root document and the cross-origin subframe document must explicitly opt in. This is the same opt-in shape as other cross-origin Fenced Frame Ads Reporting
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Fenced_Frames_Ads_Reporting.md">https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Fenced_Frames_Ads_Reporting.md</a>>features. Specifically, the root frame must opt in via the "Allow-Fenced-Frame-Automatic-Beacons" header, and the cross-origin subframe setting the data must opt in via the 'crossOriginExposed' parameter in the call to setReportEvent...().
This does not change the privacy story nor does it introduce a privacy regression, as cross-origin subframes can currently postMessage() data to the root that the root frame can then use as automatic beacon data. Both the existing capability as well as the proposed changes involve the root fenced frame document and the cross-origin subframe document opting-in to this sharing.
Blink component
Blink>FencedFrames
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFencedFrames%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EFencedFrames%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable. This feature relates to Protected Audience whose review TAG has already resolved with an "unsatisfied" position <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/723">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/723</a>>.
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This is an added functionality and is backward compatible. There are no interoperability risks as no other browsers have decided to implement these features yet.
Gecko: Negative on fenced frames <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/781">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/781</a>>
WebKit: No signal <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/173">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/173</a>>
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
Not applicable as this will not be supported on Android WebView.
Debuggability
Additional debugging capabilities are not necessary for these feature changes.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Supported on all the above platforms except Android WebView.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes. See: wpt.fyi link
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/fenced-frame?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=automatic-beacon-data">https://wpt.fyi/results/fenced-frame?label=master&label=experimental&aligned&q=automatic-beacon-data</a>>.
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Is it expected that Canary is failing all 4 tests? </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
FencedFramesCrossOriginAutomaticBeaconData
Requires code in //chrome?
False

Shipping on desktop
135
Shipping on Android
135
Anticipated spec changes
None

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Auto-generated view transition names
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Auto-generated view transition names
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Auto%5C-generated+view+transition+names%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Auto-generated view transition names</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250405" rel="nofollow">Sat, 05 Apr 2025 10:48:54 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> On 3/25/25 1:39 PM, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>On Tue, Mar 25, 2025 at 10:37 AM Vladimir Levin <vmp...@chromium.org> </tt><tt>wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
I'm not convinced this is a huge footgun. Yes, it's a convenience value that allows auto matching in MPA where there is no other way to automatically match without changes to the dom (for a custom attribute). Doing these modification is not far from just giving unique names to view-transition-name, albeit with less typing.
Is it perfect? No. I suspect that the dynamic id case that Jake gave in conjunction with auto naming is the only problematic case in that the transition won't match to what the author may want (although it's also wrong to say it isn't what they want -- it's something of which they have to be cognizant).
I agree with Noam that the discrepancy in Interop is likely cause more confusion in these cases. I'm not using Interop as justification for shipping this, but only pointing out that IMHO the problem with auto is not as severe as described in this thread.
As for the next steps, I'm fine with continuing the discussion with TAG. With respect to CSSWG, my sense is that the discussion in this thread won't sway the decision.
I'd like to understand what decision we would make here if TAG agrees with Jake's concern. Again to reiterate, the concern is valid, but is the risk of this developer confusion great enough to prevent us from adding this feature?
</pre><tt>I don't think the risk here is developer confusion. The risk is that </tt><tt>adding a unique ID attribute becomes an unsafe operation. </tt></blockquote><tt>In my experience, there's always a non-zero specificity foot gun risk </tt><tt>for non-trivial sites, depending on how your CSS is written (or more </tt><tt>likely, legacy of CSS you inherited). It sucks when you run into it, but </tt><tt>I don't think this change is novel in that sense. </tt><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>That would mean that e.g. CMSes that have multiple actors contributing </tt><tt>code to the page (e.g. the developer, the theme and plugins) would now </tt><tt>need to police/prevent all actors from using `view-transition-name: </tt><tt>auto` because some combinations of code would result in weird and hard </tt><tt>to figure-out bugs. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>That seems like a fundamental shift, which I'd argue we need to make </tt><tt>only if we have very good reasons to go that path. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On the front of interop risk of not shipping this - what happens today </tt><tt>if developers are using `auto`? Do we expect them to feature detect </tt><tt>it? And if so, what do we expect them to do in the fallback case? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Thanks, Vlad
On Tue, Mar 25, 2025, 7:37 a.m. Jake Archibald <jaffathec...@gmail.com> wrote:
I've summarised the issues with this proposal in the TAG thread
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1001#issuecomment-2750966335">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1001#issuecomment-2750966335</a>>.
On Tue, 25 Mar 2025 at 10:44, Noam Rosenthal <nrosent...@chromium.org> wrote:
*Until this feature (correct me if I'm wrong), adding a unique ID to an element was safe. With this feature, that's no longer the case.*
This seems like a worthwhile question to bring back to the TAG and/or the CSSWG. Looking at the TAG review, it doesn't seem like it was discussed.
Happy to take this back to TAG, but would defer to Vlad for next steps. Not counting on this leading to anything actionable though as Apple were very adamant about keeping things as is in the last few discussions about this, following the CSSWG process that things can stay in the spec unless there is a consensus to remove them.
This should 100% */not/* be the reasoning for shipping a feature we think is bad.
If API owners think that this is "bad" then we definitely shouldn't ship it, or ship only match-element which everyone seems to agree on. I would describe this as "not ideal" and that keeping interop on this is the lesser evil.
Are we seeing real-life interop pressure? How many sites are already using `auto`? What's the user experience in Chromium for ones that do?
It's not an existing backwards compat issue. But we'd be introducing a slight inconsistency from the get go which IMO is arguably worse than shipping the whole thing. As a web developer I'd probably end up being confused by this whole thing if Webkit and chromium end up shipping something slightly different with a lack of consensus attached to it.

entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Related+Website+Partition+%5C%28RWP%5C%29+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Related Website Partition (RWP) API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Dylan+Cutler%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Dylan Cutler' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250404" rel="nofollow">Fri, 04 Apr 2025 11:40:11 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/related-website-partition-api">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/related-website-partition-api</a></pre><pre>
Specification
None
Summary
The Related Website Partition (RWP) API is a novel mechanism for providing third-party embeds access to a partitioned, non-cookie storage handle which allows them to continue a single session across multiple domains in the same Related Website Set.
Related Website Sets <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://goo.gle/rws">http://goo.gle/rws</a>> (RWS) introduces a new privacy boundary on the web which allows sites to have access to their unpartitioned cross-site state when they are embedded on other related sites.
Blink component
Blink > Storage
Motivation
Some third-party SaaS developers embed their content on sites which are part of a Related Website Set and wish to maintain a continuous session across multiple sites within that set.
The RWP API provides a way for third parties to maintain a single session across sites in an RWS using storage that does not prompt the user and is limited only to activity within that set. This is in contrast to using the Storage Access API, which does prompt the user and grants the third party access to activity outside the current RWS.
Initial public proposal
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/first-party-sets/issues/94#issuecomment-2138292885">https://github.com/WICG/first-party-sets/issues/94#issuecomment-2138292885</a>
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1047">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1047</a>
TAG review status
Open but no feedback yet.
Risks Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: No signal
Other signals: N/A
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
No
Debuggability
None
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
No
Flag name on chrome://flags
TBD
Finch feature name
TBD, likely kRelatedWebsitePartitionAPI
Non-finch justification
None
Requires code in //chrome?
The implementation of the feature would not depend on code in //chrome.
We may modify the browser UI defined in //chrome which provides information about Related Website Sets.
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/394354282">https://crbug.com/394354282</a>
Estimated milestones
We will do an Origin Trial in M137 or M138
